Leslie Hunter likely George Leslie Hunter

element_texts.text: Completed

Brooklyn N.Y. 21 May 1929
The Arts Club Chicago.
I have trying to find a gallery in Chicago for my exhibition of paintings and etchings for nexts seasong.
and will feel obliged if you can accommodate me. Kindly inform me at your earliest possible convenience. The exhibition requires large galleries as it consists of about 65 paintings and 50 etchings, Please state your terms as to freights etc.
Yours truely
Emile Zoir likely Carl Emil Zoir
134 sixthAve, Brooklyn N.Y.

left margin annotation Hold he says -Oct 22/29
Brooklyn 18.10.29
Directors of The Chicago Art Club.
Chicago.
Dear Sri:
I shall be glad to hear of the Directors decision as to giving an exhibitions of my paintings and etchings in Chicago. I wrote you last winter but in answer was informed that the question would come before the directors this month.
Yours very truly 
Emile Zoir likely Carl Emil Zoir
242 Washington Ave.
Brooklyn, N.Y

element_texts.text: Completed

Translation from the Italian 
Emile Zoir underlined - likely Carl Emil Zoir
When trying such an experiment as to analize a prominent artist, like Emile Zoir and his works. I  do it with a certain doubt. It being a difficult thing to do in a short article and to give the true characterization of a man, whose genius already has attained universal recognition and admiration.
In the younger European art the powerful figure of Emile Zoir. Is looming strong and mighty against the darkness and despair, now enveloping the art of Europe. Zoir is the Swedish champion of modern time combatting the degeneration now prevailing.
So Nordström likely Karl Nordström,, Larson likely Carl Olof Larsson, Liljefors likely Bruno Andreas Liljefors and Zoir about thirty years ago broke through, bringing with them the new awakeded young French art and the fresh breszes blowing in Paris, where Manet, Sisley, Monet, Degas and others began a fight for light, so was Emile Zoirs name intimately tied to the modern movements in Italy,France and Germany. We find here an artist paving his way to now roads leading to higher regions of art.”Just as Whistler and Manet, who looked for new possessions in art, he has been strongly discussed. Zoir ignores the public. He leaves it to themselves to understand his preachings. In all of his works we find, that he detests the old way of copying nature, He creates but seeks his models in nature. Zoir works for creation of thoughts, instead of only attracting importance to a passing sentiment or beautiful shade of light.
It has been said that he disguises colors, but this is false judged from the canvases.I have occasion to study in the great exhibitions. I admit that color in general stands

element_texts.text: Completed

2 underlined
subordinate  to form and that lines are means of expression to a certain extent. He shows his ability to strike a cord in colors, whose originality is unquestionable.I only wish to mention “The Crucifixion” where he has in beautiful lines and touching simplicity painted the well known story of Christ from Gethsemane to the entombment. It is a masterpiece , which brings back to you the odor of religions poetry and purity. It enforces that claim to admiration which is so difficult to express in words.
The physiological atmosphere, wherein his figures are moving; maybe the element of melancholy . Let us look for instance at the great triptychon “Misery”where the composition  entirely depends on lines fo color.The results are sorrow and gloom. The artist points distinctly out how every phase in life every little change on its surface, a fleeting shadow,a pure line, gives him sensation from hidden sources.
The same can be said about the creation. Every thought which such a work imparts, belongs to the work and is one of its merits. And the nature so the art can only show us  what we are able to apprehend with our spiritual insight. Everything comes in a certain respect from ourselves.The artist possessing the creative power shows us as in a looking glass the works of his genius reflecting life itself, but translated from his standpoint. Our own conception of any special art depends upon the standpoint of our own conception, and he applies it on his paintings as well as in his etchings. His works are works of poetry, sometimes melancholy always grand. He digs deep in life, but shows it always in poetical garments.

element_texts.text: Completed

3 underlined
While we in his bigger works discern the life in its profoundness, The Italian studies give us joy of color and freshness in conception, shown on the canvas with the hand of a master in an inspired  richness of of colors , and we look enraptured at his strikethroughinspired sickness ofstrikethrough studies give of Michael - Angelos  Michelangelo frescoes in Capella Sistina  Sistine Chapel in Roma Rome as well as studies after Raphael and Rembrandt. 
Emil Zoir gives all his soul for his ideals. He possess possesses  the inspiration that belong to great men. During a period when humanity allows itself to be shaped in the same mediocre form , it is a good sign , that such a character hasn’t appeared. It is not without reason , that the art art of etching is callad [[called][ the difficult art. In order to attain the real art in etching an original conception is absolutely needed, great technical skill and experience , and only a master can handle the needle so as to give results above mediocrity Zoirs etchings must be classed as superior to anything in our modern art. Every line in these masterpises masterpieces shows us that this artist possesses a soul far above others. It is always interesting to perceive the progresses of a prominent man of culture and this becomes especially so with an artist who very different from the ordinary..This artist prossesses possesses a fund of poetical inspiration from which he pours.
Few men have had Zoirs inspiration and power to fight for his faith. His works have a swinging rythm rhythm that has been early attained. He has an extra ordinary gift to hold together a composition and in the same bewitching manner as his paintings. Genius is a power who with its fairy staff  says “let there be light” it is only in certain

element_texts.text: Completed

4 underlined
That the divine inspiration lifts itself up to the heights of the sublime and these moments are so many mileposts on the way to immorality. From the point of view of economy art is a sunday child of refinement and luxury and therfore therefore as in historical periods of Italy and France, the art was blooming, but even now in our time of (?illegible) and engineering art is advancing. Conquering laurels protected by the wealthy, and such an art as Emile Zoirsis deserving before everything an attentive understanding.
Emile Zoir is without comparison the strongest and most powerful of the younger generation of artists in Europe.Doctor W. Burgos, the famous German writer on art says. “He is a Titan who has strike-through shaken strike-though stolen the fires of heaven. He comes to us from the North underlined pouring in over us underlined The mysticism and poetry of his rich visions
Doctor Waldemar Colucci
Siena

Wilmette Nov 17.1930
annontation in pencil with shorthand marginalia Mrs. Carpenter
The Chicago Art Club
Chicago
Having just arrived from Sweden to make arrangements for my AmericanExhibitions I wish to know if the Chicago Art Club would be willing to give an exhibition of my paintings and water colors and etchings at your galleries and on what conditions.As arrangements are being made for the west
on lower left there is a stamped Newberry Library Logo James Hayes created for the Newberry Library, ca. 1950s

To the Directors of
The Chicago Art Club , Chicago

Yours very truly
Emile Zoir

element_texts.text: Completed

49 W. 72nd St.
New York City built 1929
May 28,1929
My dear Miss Jarvis,
Thank you for your prompt attention to my letter and photogrophs[[photographs][.
Would you be so good as to return the phtogrophs photographs and I will try to show them to Miss Ronmiller this summer in Europe, if you will give me her European , preferably, Paris address. Mrs. Sheldon and I are sailing July 6 for France. I enclose return postage 
Very sincerely yours,
Roy Sheldon

Chère Mademoiselle Boullier
En reutraut a Paris j’ai trouvé 
Monsieur Bosenfeld malade et
pour cette raison le paravent
pas expedie
J’ai remir anssi tot le paravent a  Chenu (l’embaleur) et la danseuse
espagnole blanche aussi. Je lui est dit qu’il faudrai faire mme caisse underlined
reparement pour l’espagnol par ce qu’elle est d’mm antre format que les panneaux du paravent
et pourait les frotter et aussi par ce cue le paravent doit underlined
Tre expedie saus passé a veut underlined
striken et-espanole qui



rue Jaques Street (43 rue de Seine)

Paris 6e underlined 24 oct 1928
Dear Miss Boullier
On the way to Paris I found
Mr. Bosenfeld was sick and
for this reason the screen
was not shipped
I put the screen back on 
I also gave the screen to Chenu (the packer) and the white Spanish dancer early.
He said he can make a crate and repair for the Spanish because it is of the same format as the panels of the screen underlined
and he can rub them and in this way they can be shipped

POSTPARKASSEN SCHECKKONTO TELEFON NUMM0ER 17-1-73
NR. 134.058
Dearest Alice - At last- I have arranged with these people for an exhibition next falll. It will be in charge of the most delightful young lady named Miss Marianne Willish Marianne Willisch who comes on her own.We are to pay the expenses one way- I.E. Express in bond to Chicago
Insurance on 18,000 shillings
2,571.00 dollars worth of stuff (no more)
freight American Express to Chicago 90.00
insurance 26.00                                    26.00 underlined

                                                            116.00 dollars

So will you send a cheque for that

amount to the address on the top of this paper. I know. striken An Exhibitions of works of Art for the Arts Club
I should think two letters alike 
one addressed  to the Americal Consul in Vienna and one to the Austrian werkbund. I gave dates 
20th of Nov or 1st Dec to Christmas using sculpture room and small Exhibition room.I hope you approve of all this - 
Madame Cuttoli likely Marie Cuttoli has postponed her coming until Oct - next. I have not yet - received your letter but - Thank you for the cable - love Rue likely  Luritia "Rue" Winterbotham Carpenter

{?)
476 SUMMIT AVENUE In St. Paul, MN
My dear Miss Roullier: likely Alice Roullier
I fancy you are back again and busy. and missing Paris as much as every one does.
It would be nice to go on lunching indefinitely at Voisin (s).
Our Art School committee is very thrilled at the prospect of having some of Ostereichers OSTERREICHISCHERS

[[Letterhead LAYTON SCHOOL OF ART - LAYTON ART GALLERY AND JEFFERSON STREET MILWAUKEE WISCONSIN- Charlotte Russell Partridge, Director 
Miriam Frink, Assistant Director]]
Jan. 12th 1929
ANNOTATION AUSTRIAN Werkbund
Dear Miss Jarvis;
Thank you ever so much for your Kind letter and also for forwarding the mail. I am expecting one more parcel with exhibiting ANNOTATION Mrs.. Hayden (s) goods from Vienna.it will contain leather goods and enamels. All the other parcels that may come stricken will contain orders which I beg you to dispose of in the way we settled. So please open the parcels even if addressed to my name.The goods received above will come per freight and Mrs. Hayden will be kind enough to settle everything regarding duty for sure.I have a letter from the Werkbund telling me stricken the that they have sent the pottery bead for Mr (Maudel?) together with the parcel you forwarded to me the other day.it has also been sent per freight and will probably arrive this week. I am very thankful for your kind offer to give me your assistance in any matter and I am looking forward

Letterhead staple hole - LAYTON ART GALLERY 438 JEFFERSON STREET MILWAUKEE WISCONSIN- Charlotte Russell Partridge, Director]]
ANNOTATION IN MARGIN Mrs. Maudel Pottery Head Invoice was 5 70 Duty 2 80 Cab. 1 30 
January 23, 1929
My dear Miss Jarvis,
The package of earthen ware of which you have been notified contains the pottery head for Mrs.(Maudel?) I am sending you an invoice for the customs enclosed within. The selling underlined price is : stricken 26bpounds each 27.30 pounds. If you would kindly deliver the head to Mrs Maudel we can settle the account on my return to Chicago. As to the 6.10 still due to the customs I have to protest against the duty rotes for the Originals as it is 8 cou then also look into this matter. ANNOTATION IN MARGIN await return
I am having very much trouble with the duty bond transfer 8 have only yesterday been notified by the customs, that this exhibit has been brought in under underlined

It is only due to stricken through. the kindness of the Milwaukee officials that I need not pay the duty for the whole underlined exhibit immediatly immediately but am given time to look into the matter or my return to Chicago.
I should appreciate it very much if you would speik speak this thing over with Q.S. Archer. I presume that you have had several exhibits brought to the States by means of a duty bound due

April 4th 1929
Studio Club
210 E 77th Sts N.Y.C.
Art Club of Chicago
412 N. Michigan Ave.
Dear Miss Jarvis,
I thank you for receipt of letter and check for 22.85 dollars which settles our account as far as these 2 orders are concerned.
Regarding the other orders I beg you to keep in mind that all additional expenses except duty line drawn to next line and your percentage are not included in the price..
As I am going to leave New York in about 2-3 weeks, please send all checks from now on to the Austrian Werkbund, 1 Kaerutuerr uip 9, Vienna Austria
direct
With Kindest regards to the other ladies and yourself,
Very sincerely yours
Marianne Willepi Marianne Willisch
